required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Serratus Plane Block vs Erector Spinae Plane Block on Postoperative Analgesia in Patients Undergoing Unilateral Breast Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of the Effects of Serratus Plane Block and Erector Spinae Plane Block on Postoperative Analgesia in Patients Undergoing Unilateral Breast Surgery

lead_sponsor.agency: Sisli Hamidiye Etfal Training and Research Hospital

clinical_study.source: Sisli Hamidiye Etfal Training and Research Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: Interfacial plan blocks are becoming more widely used for postoperative analgesia because of their easier applicability and less risk of complications. In this study, we aimed to compare the effects of serratus plane block (SPB) and erector spinae plane block (ESPB) on postoperative analgesia in patients undergoing unilateral breast surgery

primary_outcome.description: Visual analog scale (0-10), <4 is adequate analgesia
Postoperative opiodi consumption with patient controlled analgesia
If VAS score is 4 or more, paracetamol 1 gr is administered

secondary_outcome.description: Time from block performing to first analgesia requirement

arm_group.description: Serratus plane block with 25 ml %0.25 bupivacaine
Erector spinae plane block with 25 ml %0.25 bupivacaine

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ASA I-II
- Age: 18 - 65 years
- unilateral breast surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Does not approve the study
- Pregnant
- Emergency
- ASA III-IV
- History of local anesthetic allergy
- Infection in the block area
- Coagulation disorder
- Morbid obesity (body mass index> 40 kg / m²)
- Severe organ failure
- Previous neurological deficit
- Psychiatric disease
- History of chronic pain

facility.name: SBÜ Şişli Hamidiye Etfal Eğitim ve Araştırma Hastanesi

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Sisli Hamidiye Etfal Training and Research Hospital

clinical_study.keyword: serratus plane block, erector spinae plane block, postoperative analgesia
